definition: to catch (sth thrown etc)/to receive (sth given)/to accept
to receive/to answer (the phone)/to meet or welcome sb/to connect/to catch/to join/to extend/to take one's turn on duty/to take over for sb
to live/to dwell/to stay/to reside/to stop/(suffix indicating firmness, steadiness, or coming to a halt)

sentences.english: The star halfback hauled down the pass for a touchdown.
sentences.chinese: 那位明星中位接住遠傳球觸地得分。

sentences.english: The ball bounced twice before I caught it.
sentences.chinese: 球彈起兩次我才接住球。

sentences.english: People were clapping and cheering and catching the locks of hair.
sentences.chinese: 人們在鼓掌，歡呼，去接住被剪斷的髮絲。

sentences.english: I would have caught the Frisbee if the car had not been in the way.
sentences.chinese: 如果汽車沒當在中間，我就能接住飛盤了。
喏，接住你的柺棍兒，走吧。

sentences.english: She dropped the bag down and he caught it.
He then impressed his makers even more by catching two balls thrown at him at once.
sentences.chinese: 他更讓人驚奇的是能接住倆個同時投向他的球。

sentences.english: I threw the ball to John but Tom caught it.
sentences.chinese: 我把球扔給約翰，但湯姆接住了球。

sentences.english: A resident from the 9th floor tried to reach Niu by using a ladder, but failed.
sentences.chinese: 9樓的一個居民試着用梯子去接住妞妞，但是失敗了。

sentences.english: The outfielder pulled down a long drive to center-field.
sentences.chinese: 外野手快跑接住了飛向中外野的遠球。

sentences.english: Once, however, the king' s daughter failed to catch the golden ball.
sentences.chinese: 然而，有一次國王的女兒沒能將球接住。

sentences.english: He stretched out his hand and caught the falling plate.
sentences.chinese: 他一伸手接住了正在跌落的盤子。

sentences.english: It's like I throw you off a cliff, but rush to the bottom to catch you.
sentences.chinese: 這就像我將你推下懸崖，卻又拼命地衝到崖底接住你。

sentences.english: In the end, I curled up my money and threw it at the waitress who took it.
sentences.chinese: 最後，我捲起鈔票，扔向女服務員，她正好接住了。

sentences.english: The ball bounced bout twice before I caught it.
sentences.chinese: 球來回彈起兩次我才接住球。

definition: to reach out with one's hand/to hold out a hand/(fig.) to beg/to get involved/to meddle
to get out of the way
(not of regular commerce) to sell or dispose of (goods etc)/to get rid of/to unload
to relinquish one's grip/to let go
to stay out of (hot water, trouble, awkward situation etc)/to avoid (sb)
to jump up suddenly/to bound up/to rise up in one bound
conveniently/without extra trouble/while doing it/in passing
to catch/to grapple with/to hold onto
to detain/to hold back by force/to buckle/to hook
